assignments.title: Journal 1
assignments.details: Describe your experience at the Spring 2015 College of Computing Career Fair:-What was your strategy for attending? (For example: did you research companies, practice your elevator pitch, purchase a new suit...)-Describe which companies you visited and why. -Describe outcomes of your conversations with companies.-What was your overall experience like? Your journal entry should at least be between 150 and 200 words. Please attach as a PDF file.

announcements.author: Ayzenberg, Stanley Roger
announcements.title: Quick addendum to the resume review announcement
announcements.details:
Hey guys, I've been getting this a lot so just to clarify, even if you didn't turn in your resume, I'll still review it if you email it to me at sayzenberg@gatech.edu. You won't get credit for it, but I will give you feedback regardless, which will be helpful for preparing for the career fair.

Good luck to all of you!

announcements.author: Ayzenberg, Stanley Roger
announcements.title: Resume grades released, read this for more info
announcements.details:
Hey all,

We've released your resume grades, so you can go view them, along with our feedback, in the Assignments section. Overall we saw a lot of good work, but also places for improvement. While we've already graded everything, we still want you to have the best possible resumes for the career fair. So, if you want to revise your resume and then send it to me, I would be happy to look over it and provide feedback. This won't change your grade, but it might help you score that interview!

You can send me your resumes at sayzenberg@gatech.edu. Also, if you want some more immediate feedback from industry professionals, please attend Resume Reboot today in the Klaus Atrium from 10 - 4. Good luck at the career fair!

announcements.author: Rose, Ashley
announcements.title: Career Fair Information
announcements.details:
The CoC career fair is taking place next week, January 27-January 29. Here is the link to view a listing of companies that will be attending: http://www.cc.gatech.edu/student-life/career-development/career-fair-attendees

Download the GT Career Fair Plus mobile application for more in-depth company information, including positions available. Be sure to research companies of interest to you that you plan to speak with at the fair.

We will cover elevator pitches and general career fair tips in class next week. Your resumes should be returned to you by Monday. See you then!

announcements.details:
This is just a friendly reminder that you need to not only upload your resume to Tsquare under "Assignments" but you will need to bring a hard copy with you to class today.

Katie Raczynski

announcements.author: Waters, Robert L Jr
announcements.title: Venture Lab
announcements.details:
I was asked to send this to capstone students:

 
Dear Students Teams,
Last fall, I attended the Capstone Expo and was amazed by the incredible work you do. At VentureLab, we serve the faculty, staff, and students at Georgia Tech who wish to transform their research and ideas into startups. Our services are free for the GA Tech community and we take no equity in your company. We believe that some of your projects have potential for commercialization and would like to discuss those opportunities with you.
 
Sign up for an info session here.
 
Questions?
Email Ernesto Escobar
VentureLab at GA Tech

announcements.author: Greenhalgh, David Robert
announcements.title: GIT MAD officer elections tonight!
announcements.details:
Hey all,

Tonight is the last GIT MAD meeting of the semester, and it's an important one - elections. We'll be looking forward to the future of the club and those who lead it with an open discussion on what you'd like to see from GIT MAD in the future.

Use the following link to nominate people for GIT MAD leadership: goo.gl/3fmcug

Nominate anyone that you feel would be good for the role. Feel free to nominate yourself, and you can nominate multiple people for multiple positions. We'll be accepting nominations for the rest of the day.

We'll see you there!

announcements.author: Greenhalgh, David Robert
announcements.title: App-a-thon details
announcements.details:
Hey all,

We're a few hours away from the start of the App-a-thon, so here's a few more details about the event.

We'll start at 6:30pm in Klaus 1447 and 1456, and you'll have from then until 10am to build a mobile app or a web app. You app could be anything! The only rule is that you can't have brought any previously written code in. 

You can group up in teams of up to three people, or fly solo. If you'd like to RSVP your team, you can use this form to do so. If you're looking for a team, you can use this form and we'll help match you with a team. Even if you don't have an idea or aren't confident in your abilities, come on out anyway - you'll be surprised what you can accomplish.

We'll have Moe's for dinner, Domino's pizza at midnight, and Chick-fil-a for breakfast. We'll also have snacks and drinks all night.

We have 5 prize categories where we'll be giving away Surfaces, iPad Minis, Nexus phones, and more. Plus, we'll raffle away an absurd amount of books and devices.

I look forward to seeing you there!

announcements.author: Greenhalgh, David Robert
announcements.title: Come on out to the App-a-thon this Friday!
announcements.details:
Hey all,

The App-a-thon is upon us!

Tomorrow Friday April 11th from 6:30pm till Saturday April 12th at
10:30am, come flex your mobile and web app development muscles. You'll have the chance to win some great tablets, smartwatches, phones, and lots of other prizes. We'll also be holding hourly raffle prizes, and the raffle prize list this year is huge. 
 
If you want to go ahead and sign up early, use this form to register your team
of up to 3 members. If you do not have a team yet, you can use this form,
where you can fill out your skills and mention wether or not you have any project ideas to 
contribute. This way, people looking for teams before/during the App-a-thon that are looking
for more team members can look off the free agent list and contact you.
 
We look forward to seeing everyone and the really incredible apps everyone comes up with.

See you there!

announcements.author: Greenhalgh, David Robert
announcements.title: GIT MAD 2014-2015 officer nominations
announcements.details:
Hey all,

This upcoming Monday, GIT MAD will be holding officer elections for the 2014-2015 school year, and you can be involved in the process.

Use the following link to nominate: goo.gl/3fmcug

Nominate anyone that you feel would be good for the role. Feel free to nominate yourself, and you can nominate multiple people for multiple positions. We'll be accepting nominations from now until Monday, 4/14.

Being a GIT MAD officer has been a great experience, and I highly encourage anyone who's interested to applying to do so. Any of the present officers would be happy to answer questions that you may have.

Best,

David

announcements.author: Greenhalgh, David Robert
announcements.title: GIT MAD meeting tonight!
announcements.details:
Hey all,

Tonight at 6:30pm in CoC 017, we'll be talking about publishing your applications - a topic we haven't touched on before. We'll touch on the publishing process, localization, building your APK, and more.

Food and drinks will be served. See you tonight!

assignments.title: Group Project Proposal
assignments.details:
One member of your group should submit the project proposal as an attached document (.doc, .docx, or .rtf--NO .PDFs, please) to T-Square by the deadline. Although you are welcome to organize your document by addressing each of the numbered items below, you must address them in full sentences. The document must include the following:
 
  1. The names of the people in your group (and the name of your group, if it has one).
  2. The working title of your project. This should be specific, not generic (in other words, not "Group Project on Heavy Metal") and should convey a sense of the envisioned scope of the project and the approach you plan to take. In other words, it should tell me something about the project in addition to its topic. The working title can be changed later.
  3. A description of the "deliverables" the project will entail. Remember: it can take the form of a traditional written assignment (for example, a long paper with sections or chapters written by different group members), a website or other multimedia project, a video, an audio documentary, any combination of these things, or possibly other things you may have in mind. You should be very clear on just what the concrete products of this project will be, how many there will be, etc.
Please note that whatever form your project takes, you are obligated to make clear what research you did for it, what sources you used, and what you took from each source. This is easily done in a paper via footnotes or endnotes, but may take some creativity in other projects. Please indicate how you will address this issue.
 
You do not have to list the presentation your group will make during the last week of the semester as a deliverable unless the presentation will be the primary form of your project (i.e., a performance). If so, you need to explain clearly and in detail what will happen during the presentation and what tangible materials you will convey afterward (e.g., a script, a record of the research you did and how you used it, etc.).
  1. A summary of the project, including the scope of the project (what specifically you expect to cover), the approaches you will be taking to the material, what questions you are trying to answer through the project, what it will contribute to the course, and anything else you can think of to give me a clear and concrete sense of what I will be getting. Please include some specifics, such as artists and even songs you plan to address. This may require some preliminary research.
  2. A summary of the division of labor within the group: what each group member has agreed to contribute. Please note: the division of labor is clearly dependent on the form of the project, and is entirely up to you. However, the proposal must state what each person will be doing, not how much of the work each person will contribute.
Remember: this is truly a proposal, which means that I may accept or reject it, accept it with modifications, etc. If there are significant issues with the original proposal, I reserve the right to ask you (as a group) to revise it or redo it.
 
A few other things:
 
  • Remember that this is a course in Performance Studies. All projects must focus on and highlight the performance dimension of the topic. For example, just talking about songs and their thematic content will not be enough. This should be clear from the working title and the description of the project.
  • It is crucial that both your topic and proposal be as specific as possible.
  • I am more than happy to help you with this project at any stage, including the proposal stage. As you get to work on the project, I will be glad to meet with a group or its representatives to talk with you about your progress, give you ideas or suggestions, etc. 
  •  I am not willing, however, to intervene in a group's internal workings. Do not come to me with interpersonal issues. Whatever the problems may be, work them out among yourselves. Remember that every member of the group will ultimately receive the same grade for this proposal and all other aspects of the project, including the in-class presentation of the project during the last week of the term, and all deliverables.
If you have any questions about this proposal or the group project assignment, just ask.

Invisible Theater Example
"Invisible Theater" is a concept created by the globally influential Brazilian theater maker Augusto Boal (1931 - 2009) as one of the means he developed to create performances he hoped would spur social change or at least dialogue around social issues.
